resource.name: 2017 CEV: Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering Supplement
resource.description:
The Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering (CEV) Supplement is the most robust longitudinal survey about volunteerism and other forms of civic engagement in the United States. Produced by AmeriCorps in partnership with the U.S. Census Bureau, the CEV takes the pulse of our nation’s civic health every two years. The data on this page was collected in September of 2017. The CEV can support evidence-based decision making and efforts to understand how people make a difference in communities across the country.

For topline findings from the 2017 CEV, please see:
1) National rates of all measures https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-National-Rates-of-All-Measu/rhng-qtzw
2) National rates of all measures by demographics https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-National-Rates-of-All-Measu/bhmf-84dy
3) State-level rates of all measures https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-State-Level-Rates-of-All-Me/4r6x-re58

We encourage all users to download and review the following resources provided as attachments to this dataset:
1) CEV FAQs – answers to frequently asked technical questions about the CEV
2) 2017 CEV Analytic Data and Setup Files – analytic dataset in Stata (.dta) and Excel (.csv) formats, codebook for analytic dataset, and Stata code (.do) to convert raw dataset to analytic formatting produced by AmeriCorps
3) 2017 Technical Documentation – codebook for raw dataset and full supplement documentation produced by U.S. Census Bureau
4) 2017 CEV Raw Data and Read In Files – raw dataset in Stata (.dta) format, Stata code (.do) and dictionary file (.dct) to read ASCII dataset (.dat) into Stata using layout files (.lis)

resource.name: 2021 CEV: Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering Supplement
resource.description:
The Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering (CEV) Supplement is the most robust longitudinal survey about volunteerism and other forms of civic engagement in the United States. Produced by AmeriCorps in partnership with the U.S. Census Bureau, the CEV takes the pulse of our nation’s civic health every two years. The data on this page was collected in September of 2021. The CEV can support evidence-based decision making and efforts to understand how people make a difference in communities across the country.

For topline findings from the 2021 CEV, please see:
1) Volunteering and Civic Life in America research https://americorps.gov/about/our-impact/volunteering-civic-life
2) National rates of all measures https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-National-Rates-of-All-Measu/rhng-qtzw
3) National rates of all measures by demographics https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-National-Rates-of-All-Measu/bhmf-84dy
4) State-level rates of all measures https://data.americorps.gov/Volunteering-and-Civic-Engagement/2017-2021-CEV-Findings-State-Level-Rates-of-All-Me/4r6x-re58

We encourage all users to download and review the following resources provided as attachments to this dataset (click on "Show More" to view):
1) 2021 CEV Top Line Findings - slides from January 27, 2023 presentation of top line findings
2) 2021 CEV Dataset Fact Sheet – brief summary of technical aspects of the 2021 CEV dataset
3) CEV FAQs – answers to frequently asked technical questions about the CEV
4) 2021 CEV Analytic Data and Setup Files – analytic dataset in Stata (.dta) and Excel (.csv) formats, codebook for analytic dataset, and Stata code (.do) to convert raw dataset to analytic formatting produced by AmeriCorps
5) 2021 CEV Technical Documentation – codebook for raw dataset and full supplement documentation produced by U.S. Census Bureau
6) 2021 CEV Nonresponse Analysis – technical report produced by U.S. Census Bureau
7) 2021 CEV Raw Data and Read In Files – raw dataset in Stata (.dta) format, Stata code (.do) and dictionary file (.dct) to read ASCII dataset (.dat) into Stata using layout files (.lis)

resource.name: 2017-2021 CEV Findings: National Rates of All Measures from the Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering Supplement
resource.description:
The Current Population Survey Civic Engagement and Volunteering (CEV) Supplement is the most robust longitudinal survey about volunteerism and other forms of civic engagement in the United States. Produced by AmeriCorps in partnership with the U.S. Census Bureau, the CEV takes the pulse of our nation’s civic health every two years. The CEV can support evidence-based decision making and efforts to understand how people make a difference in communities across the country. 

The findings on this page are based on data collected in September of 2017, 2019, and 2021. All figures are weighted to account for the random selection of eligible respondents and missing data due to nonresponse. They reflect national rates of 17 measures of civic engagement. Please see column descriptions for details.

A spreadsheet with all of these figures is provided as an attachment along with additional resources about the CEV data. Click on "Show More" to view and download.

For the full CEV datasets, please see https://data.americorps.gov/browse?q=cev&sortBy=last_modified&utf8=%E2%9C%93 

For more top-line findings from the CEV, please see https://americorps.gov/about/our-impact/volunteering-civic-life
columns_name: National Talking with Friends and Family Rate
National Taking Action with Neighbors Rate
National Donating to a Political Cause Rate
National Rate of Voting in Local Elections
National Discussing Issues with Neighbors Rate
National Discussing Issues with Friends and Family Rate
columns_description: estimated share of Americans who talked to or spent time with friends and family at least once in the past year

estimated share of employed Americans whose workplace or employer asked or encouraged employees to volunteer or contribute to a specific cause, for example by participating in an employer-sponsored volunteering day, providing pro bono services, or donating to a charity in the past year
estimated share of Americans who bought or boycotted products or services based on the political values or business practices of that company in the past year
estimated share of Americans who got together with other people from their neighborhood to do something positive for their neighborhood or the community in the past year
estimated share of Americans who attended a public meeting, such as a zoning or school board meeting, to discuss a local issue in the past year
estimated share of Americans who contacted or visited a public official – at any level of government – to express their opinion in the past year
estimated share of Americans who spent any time volunteering for any organization or association in the past year
estimated share of Americans who gave money or possessions with a combined value of more than $25 to a political organization, party, or campaign in the past year
estimated share of Americans 18 years and older who were eligible and voted in the last local elections, such as for mayor or school board, in the past year
estimated share of Americans who discussed political, societal, or local issues with neighbors at least once in the past year

estimated share of Americans who exchanged favors with neighbors such as house sitting, watching each other’s children, lending tools, and other things to help each other at least once in the past year
estimated share of Americans who posted views about political, societal, or local issues on the internet or social media at least once in the past year
estimated share of Americans who discussed political, societal, or local issues with friends or family at least once in the past year
estimated share of Americans who read, watched or listened to news or information about political, societal, or local issues at least once in the past year
estimated share of Americans who had a conversation or spent time with neighbors at least once in the past year

estimated share of Americans who gave money or possessions with a combined value of more than $25 to a non-political group or organization such as a charity, school, or religious organization in the past year
estimated share of Americans who belonged to any groups, organizations, or associations in the past year

resource.name: Segal AmeriCorps Education Award: Detailed Payments by Institution 2019
columns_description: The type of payment. Education expenses; Repay qualified loans; Uncategorized; Returns. Returns (to CNCS from the Institution) may indicate canceled or returned payments made in error. Sum of payments grouped by this payment type should account for returned amounts (negative values) in order to build an accurate figure. Returns are not associated with either of the other payment types and must be inferred through the context of the payments to the institution by year.
The total amount of Segal AmeriCorps Education Award and Interest payments made to the institution.
Name of the U.S. State or Territory. (INTL indicates international payment)
The type of award earned by the AmeriCorps member; Interest, Education, or Other.
The fiscal year in which the treasury payment was made to the institution.
Name of the higher education or loan processing institution.
Name of the higher education system of schools. (May be incomplete or missing.)
Name of the higher education institution campus. (if available)
Name of the higher education institution college. (i.e. School of Law)

domain_metadata.value: (1) Includes all Segal AmeriCorps Education payment types, including interest payments. (2) Institution, System, Campus, College, and State are data values were reviewed and cleaned by CNCS staff to increase standardization. The cleaning process includes multiple types of changes including; adjusting abbreviations, fixing spelling errors, updating the name if ownership changed or as otherwise changed by the institution, or reflecting the name of the higher ed institution if payment was handled by a loan processing organization but the higher ed institution name was present in CNCS records associated with the payment, among other change types. (3) Changes are current as of August 2020 and are subject to change on further review. (4) Changes do not affect the CNCS system of record managed by the National Service Trust and are made for the purpose of easier public consumption of the data. (5) Systems, campus, and colleges may be incomplete or missing. If you believe a system should be added to the dataset or if another record is in error, please write to opendata@cns.gov with the current name and state of the institution and the recommended change. (6) Payments by payment type may be either positive or negative. The sum of all payments per institution will reflect the accurate total per the institution without further additional adjustments to the payment value. (7) Count of payments includes returned or canceled payments ($0). (8) Payment to eligible institutions is made on behalf of the AmeriCorps member or recipient of transferred awards at their request. AmeriCorps members must use their award within seven years of completing their term of service. Recipients of transferred awards must use the award within ten years from the date the education award was earned. (9) Repay loan payments are those made to qualified student loans. Qualified student loans is defined as a loan backed by the federal government under Title IV of the Higher Education Act (except PLUS Loans to parents of students) or under Titles VII or V

AmeriCorps Segal Education Award payment data is collected and maintained by the National Service Trust. Payment to eligible institutions is made on behalf of the AmeriCorps member or recipient of a transferred award at their request. AmeriCorps members must use their award within seven years of completing their term of service. Recipients of transferred awards must use the award within ten years from the date the education award was earned.

resource.name: CNCS State Profiles 2016-2017 - Programs / Projects and Service Locations
resource.description: This dataset contains summary data on the location of sites where AmeriCorps members and Senior Corps volunteers served between 2/10/2016 and 2/10/2017, as well as the administrative location of all CNCS-supported programs and projects from the same time period. This dataset is drawn from the CNCS State Profiles 2016-2017 reports.
resource.attribution: Corporation for National and Community Service
columns_description:
Service Location -
 Location of site where AmeriCorps members or Senior Corps volunteers served; Program/Project Location - Administrative site of CNCS-supported program or project, where services may or may not have been provided
Major streams of service and sources of funds within CNCS
USDA Department of Agriculture Rural-Urban Continuum Codes based on population
US Congressional District associated with service state / territory
State associated with service location address; CNCS uses USPS State abbreviation; Some Service Locations may be connected to Programs located in other states/territories
NCCC Campus associated with the NCCC team providing the service
4-digit extended USPS Zip +4 associated with program ZIP; Note: leading zeros (0) may be missing. Unique zip codes (without USPS assigned +4) will be blank
US Congressional District associated with program state / territory
County name associated with the program administrative location address
State associated with program administrative location address; CNCS uses USPS State abbreviation; Programs may be connected to Service Locations located in other states/territories
County name associated with the service location address
USDA Department of Agriculture Rural-Urban Continuum Codes based on population
5-digit ZIP code associated with program administrative location address; CNCS uses USPS Zip Code; Note: leading zeros (0) may be missing
Major service streams consist of corporate programs that further delineate the support provided
4-character American Indian / Alaska Native / Native Hawaiian (AIANNH) area census code
Name of city associated with service location address; CNCS uses US Place Name to populate this entry
Latitude and longitude using the location type address as source
System assigned unique ID; National subgrantee grant (except SIF) and operating site IDs are not included in the 2016-2017 State Profiles dataset
5-digit ZIP code associated with service location address; CNCS uses USPS Zip Code; Note: leading zeros (0) may be missing
System assigned unique ID; Blank value due to award made by Intermediaries outside of CNCS' transaction system
Name of the program/project that implements or otherwise oversees services
System assigned unique ID; Blank value due to award made by Intermediaries outside of CNCS' transaction system
Name of program's administrative location city; CNCS uses US Place Name to populate this entry
4-character American Indian / Alaska Native / Native Hawaiian (AIANNH) area census code
4-digit extended USPS Zip +4 associated with service ZIP; Note: leading zeros (0) may be missing. Unique zip codes (without USPS assigned +4) will be blank

domain_metadata.value: Corporation for National and Community Service
Corporation for National and Community Service

(1) The locations in this dataset are not “real time,” meaning they are not necessarily active on the date of viewing this dataset. (2) Due to varying performance and reporting periods and requirements, both across and within CNCS programs, some data values may appear as zero or blank in this dataset. (3) Location data is masked so as not to reveal the exact street address of potentially sensitive service sites and programs. The location remains in the general vicinity of the actual location. Some sites may be completely masked due to beneficiary privacy concerns. (4) Services may be provided at some Program/Project Locations as well as Service Locations, either by members and volunteers or by the organization directly. (5) The ‘AmeriCorps Territory’ code does not include the U.S. Territories Guam or Puerto Rico, which are managed as AmeriCorps State Competitive and AmeriCorps State Formula awards. (6) The ‘AmeriCorps State Without Commission’ code is for single state direct project relationships between CNCS and the grantee. These can include programs operating in a state without a state commission or some special program types, such as some justice AmeriCorps programs. (7) ‘AmeriCorps Indian Tribes’ may not include all awards to tribal entities. (8) Locations data found in the dataset that are not rendering on maps may have latitude/longitude or underlying address inaccuracies. (9) All other limitations and notations relevant to the CNCS State Profiles 2016-2017 reports are attributable to this dataset. For more information, see Source Link. (10) CNCS is not responsible for the quality or accuracy of analyses and reports created from this dataset by non-CNCS entities.
This dataset comes from administrative data provided to CNCS by grantee/sponsor organizations.

resource.name: State Profile Geospatial Data
resource.description: This dataset is used to produce the CNCS state profile map for use on our website.

resource.name: 2018 AmeriCorps NCCC Hometowns
resource.description: AmeriCorps members from all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories have been called to communities impacted. These AmeriCorps members make up CNCS’s elite, specialty-trained disaster response crews. Their service includes volunteer and donation management, disaster survivor assistance, operations and logistics, damage assessments, muck and gut operations, and more.
